items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
After careful review of the material presented by the tenure review committee for each candidate and the written evaluations and supporting materials submitted by the committee, Board approval is requested for the following recommendations to award tenure and to reemploy for the following academic year:
	 
De Anza College:
	 
Jason Bram – Biology
Alicia De Toro – Environmental Sciences
Russell Hong – Speech
Nick Mattis – Physical Education
Michael McCart – Automotive Technology
Roseanne Quinn - English
Jeff Staudinger – Environmental Sciences
Danielle Von Matt – Physical Education
	 
Foothill College:
	 
Rachelle Campbell – Radiologic Technology
Milissa Carey - Music
Lisa Drake - Accounting
Amelia Edwards - Biology
LeeAnn Emanuel - Counseling
John Fox - Sociology
Mary Holland - Chemistry
Benjamin Stefonik - Psychology
Angela Su – Pharmacy Technology
	 
	 
*Advancement in the tenure process is contingent upon having met all requirements including having served a complete probationary contract year. A probationary faculty employee is deemed to have completed a probationary contract year if he or she provides service for 75 percent of the academic year. If the probationary faculty employee serves less than 75 percent of an academic year, the year shall be considered a “prob zero” year and shall not count for tenure. In such cases the tenure process is interrupted by the prob zero year and shall be resumed in the subsequent academic year in which the faculty employee is able to perform services for 75 percent of the academic year.
	 
	 
Submitted by:
 Dorene Novotny, Vice Chancellor of Human Resources and Equal Opportunity, ext. 6211
Additional contact names:
 n/a
Is backup provided?
 Yes

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
New board policy 2360 regarding governing board meeting minutes was presented for first reading at the February 3, 2014, meeting.  The policy delegates to the chancellor the responsibility for ensuring that minutes are taken at all governing board meetings, actions of the Board are recorded, and the record of action is made available to the public. Language included in the proposed policy is derived directly from the referenced sections of California's Education and Government codes.
	 
The proposed new policy was approved by the Chancellor's Advisory Council electronically on October 18, 2013.
	 
References:
Education Code Section 72121(a)
Government Code Section 54957.5
	 
Submitted by:
Linda Thor
Additional contact names:
					 
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Chancellor Linda Thor recommends adoption of new board policy 2360 regarding minutes of Board of Trustees meetings.
items.item_text: Board Policy 2360 Minutes - New (Second Reading)
items.item_text_raw: 2. Board Policy 2360 Minutes - New (Second Reading)

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
New board policy 2365 regarding the recording of governing board meetings was presented for first reading at the February 3, 2014, meeting.  The policy sets forth provisions of Government Code sections 54953.5 and 54953.6 that permit audio or video recording of meetings by members of the public and require any district recording to be made available under the Public Records Act.
	 
The proposed new policy was approved by the Chancellor's Advisory Council electronically on October 18, 2013.
	 
References:
Education Code Section 72121(a)
Government Code Section 54953.5 and 54953.6
	 
Submitted by:
Linda Thor
Additional contact names:
					 
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Chancellor Linda Thor recommends adoption of new board policy 2365 regarding the recording of governing board meetings.
items.item_text: Board Policy 2365 Recording - New (Second Reading)
items.item_text_raw: 3. Board Policy 2365 Recording - New (Second Reading)

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Revised board policy 2410 (formerly 2615) regarding the district's board policies and administrative procedures was presented for first reading at the February 3, 2014, meeting. Based on input received at the meeting, “and the public” was added to the policy language statement regarding availability of board policies and administrative procedures on the district web site. The proposed revisions update language to clarify the purposes and limitations of board policies and administrative procedures and define the manner in which policies may be adopted or revised. Additionally, the policy number has been changed to align with the Community College League of California Policy and Procedure Service templates. Added language is indicated on the attachment by bold, underlined text, while deleted text is represented by strikethrough. 
	 
The policy revisions were approved electronically by the Chancellor's Advisory Council on October 18, 2013.
	 
References:
Education Code Section 70902
Accreditation Standard IV.B.1.b and e
	 
Submitted by:
Linda Thor
Additional contact names:
					 
Is backup provided?
No
items.item_recommendation: Chancellor Linda Thor recommends adoption of revised board policy 2410 (formerly 2615) regarding the district's board policies and administrative procedures.

items.item_text_raw: 4. Board Policy 2410 (formerly 2615) Policy and Administrative Procedure - Revised (Second Reading)

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The provisions of board policy 7337 (formerly 4510) regarding employee fingerprinting have been expanded to include temporary employees, volunteers, and some student workers. Additionally, language has been added to specify convictions that disqualify individuals from employment. Added language is indicated on the attachment by bold, underlined text, while deleted text is represented by strikethrough. 
	 
The revised policy was presented for first reading at the February 3, 2014, Board of Trustees meeting and approved electronically by the Chancellor's Advisory Council on October 18, 2013.
	 
References:
Education Code Sections 87010, 87011, 87013, and 88024
Penal Code Sections 11102.2 and 11077.1
	 
Submitted by:
Linda Thor
Additional contact names:
Dorene Novotny
Is backup provided?
Yes

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
As noted in the December 10, 2012, Board Agenda item titled "Update on Proposition 30, Education Protection Account," the language in Proposition 30 requires that all California community college districts have sole authority to determine how the moneys received from the Educational Protection Account are spent in the school or schools within its jurisdiction, provided:
The appropriate governing board or body shall make these spending determinations in open session of a public meeting of the governing board or body and shall not use any of the funds from the Education Protection Account for salaries or benefits of administrators or any other administrative costs
Shall annually publish on its Internet Website an accounting of how much money was received from the Education Protection Account and how that money was spent
Shall, in addition to all other requirements of law, ascertain and verify through the annual independent audit whether the funds provided from the Education Protection Account have been properly disbursed and expended as required by this section.
Attached for reference is the April 3, 2013, California Community Colleges Chancellor's Office Accounting Advisory, to assist districts with compliance for the language in Proposition 30, as noted above.
	 
This Board action contains the recommended spending plan for the District's Proposition 30 allocation for the 2013-14 fiscal years per the propositions's guidelines and the Accounting Advisory (see attached report).  
	 
For the adopted budget, we budgeted to receive $20,979,988, the same as what was received for 2012-13.  It is relevant to note that this is not new, additional funding to the District.  The District will apply these designated funds as needed to the instructional and student support categories included in the spending plan until the amount received from the EPA is reached.  No funds will be applied to administrator's salaries or benefits, or any other administrative costs.  The District will post on its website an accounting of what the final 2013-14 allocation of EPA funds was to the District and how it was expended.  This will not take place until late September after the financial books for 2013-14 have been closed.  Additionally, the expenditure of the funds will be included in the CCFS-311 report to the state chancellor's office and the annual financial audit will include verification that the funds were used as required by Proposition 30.  
	 
Submitted by:
Kevin McElroy, Vice Chancellor of Business Services, x6202
Additional contact names:
Joni Hayes, Interim Director of Budget Operations
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Approve the 2013-14 Spending Plan for the Proposition 30, Educational Protection Account (EPA)
items.item_text: 2013-14 Spending Plan for the Proposition 30, Educational Protection Account (EPA)
items.item_text_raw: 7. 2013-14 Spending Plan for the Proposition 30, Educational Protection Account (EPA)

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The District owns surplus furniture that has been replaced with new (see attached lists, 11 pages).  It has been determined that the furniture is old and at the end of life or is in such poor condition that it is unusable.  District staff estimates the value of this furniture to be less than $100.00 in the aggregate.
	 
California Education Code 81452(c) provides that if the governing board, by a unanimous vote of those members present, finds that the property, is of insufficient value to defray the costs of arranging a sale, the property may be disposed of in the local public dump on order of any employee of the District empowered for that purpose by the board.
	 
District Staff will dismantle the items and recycle or dispose of the components appropriately.
	 
Submitted by:
Pam Grey, Director, Purchasing Services
Additional contact names:
Eric Olague, Buyer, Purchasing Services
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Make a finding that the items are of insufficient value to defray the costs of arranging a sale and authorize the Director of Purchasing Services to recycle the items or dispose of them in the local public dump.
items.item_text: Recycle and Dispose of Surplus Furniture
items.item_text_raw: 8. Recycle and Dispose of Surplus Furniture

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The District has ten pallets of computers, monitors, printers, and miscellaneous electronic equipment (See attached Surplus Forms, 13 pages).  The District’s Educational Technology Services Department (ETS) staff has determined that the items are obsolete and of no further use to the District.  In accordance with the Electronic Waste Recycling Act these items are considered electronic waste. The estimated aggregate market value of this electronic equipment is less than $5,000.00.
	 
California Education Code 81452(a) provides that if the governing board, by a unanimous vote of those members present, finds that the property, whether one or more items, does not exceed in value the sum of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00), the property may be sold by any employee of the District empowered for that purpose by the board. 
	 
Purchasing Services will post a notice on Bid Net and call for competitive bids from authorized State of California material handlers, collectors, and recyclers.  Proceeds will be deposited to the District’s general fund. 
	 
Submitted by:
Pam Grey, Director, Purchasing Services
Additional contact names:
Eric Olague, Buyer, Purchasing Services
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Make a finding that the property does not exceed $5,000.00 in value and authorize the Director of Purchasing Services to sell the items in accordance with Education Code 81452(a).
items.item_text: Sale of Miscellaneous Surplus Electronic Equipment
items.item_text_raw: 9. Sale of Miscellaneous Surplus Electronic Equipment

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Approval of Clockwork application purchase and implementation for both colleges DSPS departments
	 
Clockwork application is a comprehensive, specialized scheduling and database tracking system for disabled students. Foothill College and De Anza College working independently and together with ETS came to the conclusion this is a good comprehensive solution for the purpose it was designed for. This application is produced and maintained by Microcomputer Science Center, a Canadian Corporation located at Ontario, Canada.
	 
By regulatory requirements, both colleges need to implement this system to keep track of disabled students for their special accommodation needs (accommodation notifications), it also requires both colleges’ support staff to enter support notes, track progress improvements, and other related activities performed at both colleges for special needs of DSPS students. Most importantly, implementing Clockwork will allow both colleges to accurately track student headcount and contact with DSPS offices for funding purposes.
	 
Toward this end, both colleges evaluated and selected the Clockwork application system. This system has been utilized by many other colleges and universities for this purpose.
	 
ETS reviewed the technical requirements of the system, and provided assistance and advice to both colleges after the initial selection, this application package has also been evaluated and prioritized by the technology task force committee of both colleges.
	 
In order to start the implementation process, district requests board approval to enter into a new contract with Microcomputer Science Center, which will provide the necessary license, implementation, training and maintenance of Clockwork software to both colleges.
	 
Cost summary of the Clockwork application package:
	 
					 
$/year
One time fixed cost
$84,425
2nd year maintenance
$11,766
3rd year maintenance
$12,354
Total 3 year cost
$108,545
	 
The subsequent maintenance cost after 3rd year will escalate @5% based on the 3rd year’s maintenance cost.
	 
Submitted by:
Joseph Moreau, Vice Chancellor of Technology, x6120
Additional contact names:
Chien Shih, Director of Information Systems & Operations, x 6139
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: ETS requests the boardâs approval to enter into a contract with Microcomputer Science Center to implement the Clockwork application package at both colleges.
items.item_text: Approval of Clockwork Application
items.item_text_raw: 10. Approval of Clockwork Application

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
In accordance with Education Code 87469, a probationer faculty employee must serve at least 75% service of a full-time assignment for the academic year for the year to be counted as a year of service as a probationary employee. Further, in accordance with Education Code 87776 time spent on any unpaid leave of absence shall not be included in computing the service required as a prerequisite to attainment of, or eligibility for, tenure.
	 
The following probationer faculty employee shall be reemployed as follows:
	 
Phase I 2013-2014 to Phase I 2014-2015
	 
De Anza College
Debra Dobosz - Nursing
	 
	 
*Advancement in the tenure process is contingent upon having met all requirements including having served a complete probationary contract year. A probationary faculty employee is deemed to have completed a probationary contract year if he or she provides service for 75 percent of the academic year. If the probationary faculty employee serves less than 75 percent of an academic year, the year shall be considered a “prob zero” year and shall not count for tenure. In such cases the tenure process is interrupted by the prob zero year and shall be resumed in the subsequent academic year in which the faculty employee is able to perform services for 75 percent of the academic year.
	 
Submitted by:
Dorene Novotny, Vice Chancellor of Human Resources and Equal Opportunity, ext. 6211
Additional contact names:
n/a
Is backup provided?
Yes

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The Celebrity Forum Speaker Series has been a part of Foothill College for 46 years. The series is an important community event and draws thousands of people each year to Flint Center. From its founding in 1968, the series has been completely self-supporting and has never used District or college funds for its operation, being financed solely through ticket sales. The series has always been a financial success and has contributed valuable discretionary dollars to Foothill College.
	 
The Foothill College Celebrity Forum has secured October 22, 23, 24, 2014 for lectures by Bill Nye through his representative at Greater Talent Network. The agreed upon fees for the three appearances is $120,000. This fee does not include travel expenses. Half of this fee will be used as a deposit to lock in Bill Nye's appearances and is due immediately.  The remaining half will be due before his actual appearances in October.
	 
This item is being submitted to the board for contract approval.
	 
Submitted by:
Judy C. Miner
Additional contact names:
Richard Henning, Bernata Slater
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: The Foothill College Administration recommends approval of the Celebrity Forum contract.
items.item_text: Celebrity Forum Independent Contractor Agreement
items.item_text_raw: 15. Celebrity Forum Independent Contractor Agreement

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The district's Parking and Traffic Regulations permit the Board of Trustees to approve a waiver or reduction of parking fees. Foothill College President Judy Miner requests that the following parking lot rental fees be waived because the host organizations' objectives support the college mission:
	 
March 8, 2014 - Foothill College Parking Lot 1 - $650 nonprofit rental fee
Summer Search is a nonprofit organization that works with low-income high school students to build leadership skills and a college-going mindset. The organization has rented the Foothill College track for a run clinic on March 8, 2014. Student participants and their families, who have a median income of $24,813 per year, will park in Lot 1.
	 
April 19, 2014 - Foothill College Parking Lot 7 - $425 nonprofit rental fee
Hidden Villa Farm is a nonprofit organization that teaches environmental awareness and social justice to children through its school, community, and summer camp programs. A run/walk event to raise money for summer camp scholarships will be held on the farm on April 19, 2014, and the organization has requested use of Lot 7 to reduce traffic on Moody Road.
	 
Submitted by:
Judy Miner
Additional contact names:
					 
Is backup provided?
No
items.item_recommendation: Foothill College President Judy Miner recommends that the Board of Trustees waive the parking Lot 1 rental fees for Summer Search's March 8, 2014, run clinic and Lot 7 rental fees for Hidden Villa Farm's run/walk on April 19, 2014.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Ad Age Broadcast Network is a media-buying agency that Foothill College uses to secure online, radio and television advertising spots for the 2013-2014 FY. We use Ad Age Broadcast Network for their ability to buy media spots in bulk and pass the savings on to us. If we were to negotiate with each media group, we would not get the same quantity of coverage that we are able to get with Ad Age Broadcast Network. This buy covers five campaigns: Fall 2013, Winter 2014, Spring 2014, Summer 2014 and 2014 Day on the Hill.
	 
Submitted by:
Judy C. Miner
Additional contact names:
Bernata Slater
Is backup provided?
Yes

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Foothill seeks board approval for curriculum changes for the 2014-15 Catalog.  Per Title 5 direction, all course changes, substantial and non-substantial, must be approved by the governing board of the District before they may be submitted to the State Chancellor's Office for final approval.
	 
These courses have met Foothill’s curriculum standards and the Foothill College Curriculum Committee certifies that they are compliant with Title 5 regulations.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Foothill seeks board approval for Stand Alone Courses for the 2014-15 Catalog.  Per Title 5 direction, every course that is not part of a State approved degree or certificate or is not part of the Foothill General Education requirements requires an application to substantiate its appropriateness to our mission and prove that it has met Foothill’s curriculum standards and is compliant with regard to enrollment restrictions and accreditation standards.
	 
College Curriculum Committee applications have been completed, and the courses have been approved through the established Foothill curriculum process.
	 
Submitted by:
Judy C. Miner

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The California History Center (CHC) at De Anza College was fortunate in late 2013 to be the beneficiary of a generous gift to create the Audrey Edna Butcher Civil Rights Education Initiative. The donation will also support the long-term sustainability of the CHC.
	 
To inform the college community, honor the donor and celebrate the occasion, the college in February sponsored a reception featuring remarks from U.S. Rep. Mike Honda and performances by Emmy-winning jazz composer and musician Mark Izu. Invitees included the legislative delegation, elected officials from the county, regional cities and school districts, members of the historian and civil rights communities, and friends of the donor, college and district. For the delimited period of the reception and a related event held prior -- 1-5:30 p.m. on Wednesday, February 19, 2014 -- parking fees were waived and citations not written. This parking provision was noted on a limited basis to invitees and interested parties.
	 
Submitted by:
 Brian Murphy, President De Anza College, ext. 8706
Additional contact names:
Marisa Spatafore, Director of Marketing & Communications, ext. 8672
Tom Izu, Executive Director, California History Center, ext. 8986
Is backup provided?
 No
items.item_recommendation: De Anza College President Brian Murphy requests that the board approve this limited parking fee waiver.
items.item_text: De Anza College - Parking Fee Waiver for Audrey Edna Butcher Civil Rights Education Initiative
items.item_text_raw: 22. De Anza College - Parking Fee Waiver for Audrey Edna Butcher Civil Rights Education Initiative

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Resolution 2014-04
Foothill-De Anza Community College District Board of Trustees
	 
Resolution in Support of the 
California Community Colleges Baccalaureate Degree
	 
WHEREAS, by 2018, 63 percent of job openings will require some college education and 33 percent will require a bachelor’s degree; and
	 
WHEREAS, among the 20 most populous states, California ranks 19th in the percentage of high school graduates who enroll directly in a four-year college or university and 18th in the percentage who enroll in any college, including community colleges; and
	 
WHEREAS, since 2000, California has lost slightly more college graduates to other states than it has gained; and
	 
WHEREAS, the 110,000 bachelor’s degrees awarded annually by California public institutions and the 40,000 awarded by private institutions fall almost 60,000 degrees short of the number needed to meet projected demand in 2025; and
	 
WHEREAS, careers in public safety, technology and health services now often require no less than the baccalaureate degree; and
	 
WHEREAS, 21 states have authorized community colleges to award applied baccalaureate degrees that meet workforce demand; and
	 
WHEREAS, every person should have an opportunity to pursue the baccalaureate degree at a place that is convenient, accessible and affordable; and
	 
WHEREAS, community colleges have a proven record of meeting local workforce demands in applied and technical areas, supporting underrepresented students and providing affordable, accessible quality instruction; and
	 
WHEREAS, authorizing community colleges to offer limited, targeted applied baccalaureate degrees would increase access for underserved areas and populations, benefit the state economy, remove barriers to completion and compensate for the lack of university programs or capacity in certain fields; and
	 
WHEREAS, the California Community Colleges Baccalaureate Study Group convened in 2013 by Chancellor Brice Harris concluded that “the offering of baccalaureates by the California Community Colleges merits serious review and discussion;”
	 
NOW THEREFORE BE IT RESOLVED that the Foothill-De Anza Community College District Board of Trustees supports legislation that authorizes and funds community colleges to voluntarily offer baccalaureate degrees that address critical workforce needs, meet the needs of underrepresented students, and avoid unnecessary duplication of degree programs in a region;
	 
NOW THEREFORE BE IT FURTHER RESOLVED that the Foothill-De Anza Community College District Board of Trustees urges Chancellor Brice Harris and the Board of Governors of the California Community Colleges to proceed with an ongoing dialogue with the California State University and the University of California on this opportunity while also establishing in a collaborative fashion the criteria and processes for individual colleges to offer baccalaureate degrees.
	 
PASSED AND ADOPTED this _______th day of __________, 2014 
	 
	 
Submitted by:
Linda Thor
Additional contact names:
					 
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Chancellor Linda Thor recommends that the Board of Trustees adopt resolution 2014-04 in support of the California Community Colleges baccalaureate degree.
items.item_text: Resolution in Support of the California Community Colleges Baccalaureate Degree (ACTION)
items.item_text_raw: 23. Resolution in Support of the California Community Colleges Baccalaureate Degree (ACTION)

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
On November 4, 2014, registered voters within the Foothill-De Anza Community College District will have the opportunity to elect two members of the district governing board. The attached resolution allows the Santa Clara County Board of Supervisors to consolidate the election with other elections taking place on the same date and thereby minimize costs to the district.  Also provided for the Board's information are Specifications of the Election Order and Information Sheet, which will be submitted to the Registrar of Voters along with the adopted resolution and map of the district boundaries.
	 
Submitted by:
Linda Thor
Additional contact names:
					 
Is backup provided?
Yes

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Parcel C at the former Onizuka Air Force Station in Sunnyvale, California, was conveyed at Public Benefit Allowance discount under the authority of the Federal Property and Administrative Services Act of 1949, as amended, to Foothill-De Anza Community College District on February 14, 2013.  As required by the deed that conveyed the property, an annual utilization report which demonstrates that the property is being utilized solely and continuously in accordance with the educational program of use set forth and approved in the terms and conditions of the deed was provided to the Department of Education on February 5, 2014. 
	 
On February 12, 2014, the Department of Education acknowledged receipt of the annual report, and, in response to our request, granted a six (6) month extension until September 2016 for FHDA to begin utilizing the property as originally approved by the Department of Education.
	 
Submitted by:
Charles Allen, Executive Director
Additional contact names:
Kevin McElroy, Vice Chancellor
Is backup provided?
Yes

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The asphalt walkway between the PE-6 building and the Stadium and Track facilities has developed a sinkhole due to a faulty sanitary sewer line underground that must be repaired and replaced. A temporary walkway around the sinkhole has been provided.
	 
The scope of work in this project will require the contractor to excavate to the required depth and to shore the area to allow safe access to conduct repairs. The contractor will then replace and repair existing sanitary sewer piping and connections, replace the backfill materials and install new asphalt surface to grade per the plans.
	 
BKF Engineers prepared the construction documents and a complete set of all bid documents are on file in the Purchasing Services Department.
	 
Bid #1676 was legally advertised on January 10 and January 17, 2014.  The “Invitation to Bid” was also sent to nine (9) builders’ exchanges, advertised in the Daily Pacific Builder, and posted on “BidNet” at www.govbids.com.  Bids were publicly opened and read on February 12, 2014 at 3:00 p.m. by Purchasing Services.  The bid results are shown below:
	 
CONTRACTOR
BASE BID AMOUNT
Sanact, Inc.
$22,800
MK Pipelines, Inc.
$34,000
Casey Construction, Inc.
$47,450
Cratus, Inc.
$55,000
	 
The lowest responsive and responsible bidder is Sanact, Inc. (dba Roto-Rooter). Sanact, Inc. has successfully completed similar sanitary sewer repair projects for other public entities such as University of California, Berkeley, City of San Carlos, City of Alameda, and Oro Loma Sanitary District.
	 
The bid price of $22,800 as submitted by Sanact, Inc. is within the architect’s construction estimate of $20,000 to $25,000 plus a $5,000 allowance amount for unanticipated or unforeseen conditions, and is within the construction budget. The project will be constructed with District Capital Outlay funds.
	 
Submitted by:
  Pam Grey, Director of Purchasing Services
Additional contact names:
  Charles Allen, Tom Armstrong, Gina Bailey
Is backup provided?
   No
items.item_recommendation: Authorize the Director of Purchasing Services, Pam Grey, to award a contract pursuant to Bid #1676, in the aggregate amount of $22,800 to Sanact, Inc.
items.item_text: Award a contract pursuant to Bid #1676 PE-6 Sanitary Sewer Repairs at De Anza College (ACTION)
items.item_text_raw: 32. Award a contract pursuant to Bid #1676 PE-6 Sanitary Sewer Repairs at De Anza College (ACTION)

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
On August 29, 2011, the Board of Trustees adopted procedures for prequalification of prospective bidders for public projects in accordance with Public Contract Code section 20651.5 and Public Contract Code section 20101.
	 
The construction estimate for the De Anza Library project is $6,400,000.  On October 23 and October 30, 2014, Purchasing Services advertised the Prequalification Questionnaire (PQ) #1677-216 in the San Jose Post Record as well posted it on “Bidnet” at www.govbids.com and sent it to nine (9) local Builders’ Exchanges inviting “B” General Contractors to participate in the PQ.  Fourteen (14) contractors submitted the completed questionnaire to the District by the November 21, 2014, due date. The questionnaires were evaluated based upon the following key evaluation factors: license information, litigation history, construction experience, safety history, bonding capacity, insurance capacity, and financial capacity.  Public Contract Code Section 20101(a) mandates that the questionnaire responses of prospective bidders and their financial statements shall not be deemed public records and shall not be open to public inspection.
	 
Purchasing Services staff and the De Anza College Measure C Bond Program Director evaluated the responses and determined that eight (8) of the fourteen (14) contractors meet the minimum requirements of the prequalification questionnaire, including a point score of 80 or higher out of a total possible 100 points.
	 
SUMMARY OF RESULTS
CONTRACTOR
PREQUALIFIED
Alten Construction, Inc.
Yes
S.J. Amoroso Construction Co., Inc.
Yes
Arntz Builders, Inc.
No
Dilbeck & Sons, Inc.
Yes
D.L. Falk Construction, Inc.
Yes
James R. Griffin, Inc.
Yes
Lathrop Construction Associates, Inc.
No
Midstate Construction Corporation
No
C. Overaa & Co.
Yes
Roebbelen Contracting, Inc.
No
Swenson & Associates
Yes
Taber Construction, Inc.
No
Zolman Construction and Development, Inc.
No
Zovich Construction
Yes
	 
The Board can choose to either:
	 
          1.     Accept the list of eight (8) Contractors who met all of the prequalification requirements as the only contractors who are “pre-qualified” to bid on the De Anza College Library project,
	     OR
          2.     Cancel the pre-qualification procedure for this project.
	 
Submitted by:
Pam Grey, Director of Purchasing Services
Additional contact names:
Charles Allen, Tom Armstrong, Annette Perez
Is backup provided?
No
items.item_recommendation: Accept the list of eight (8) Contractors who met all of the prequalification requirements as the only contractors who are prequalified to bid as direct contractors on the De Anza College Measure C Project #216 - Library.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Title:  Change Order #10
Vendor:  SJ Amoroso Construction
Agreement Date:  March 3, 2013
Campus:  Foothill College
Project Number:  105
Project Name:  Modernization of Learning Support Center, Biology, and General Classrooms
Amount:  $58,122
For:
	 
Changes requested by the District and directed by the Architect.  District-requested changes authorized premium-time work by the contractor to ensure completion for academic use, and included replacement of old batteries in the fire alarm system and a change in data cabling specification to meet new ETS standards.  Architect-directed changes include revisions to the lighting plan in bldg. 5100, fire sprinkler layouts, ductwork and framing, and miscellaneous changes to the design needed to complete the work.
	 
This change plus all previously approved change orders equal to 8.4% of the base contract value.   Funding for this change is included in the project budget.
	 
Submitted by:
Charles Allen, Executive Director, Facilities, Operations, and Construction Management, extension 6150
Additional contact names:
Art Heinrich, Director, Bond Program Management, Foothill College
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Approval
items.item_text: SJ Amoroso Construction - Change Order #10 - Modernization of Learning Support Center, Biology, and General Classrooms - $58,122
items.item_text_raw: F) SJ Amoroso Construction - Change Order #10 - Modernization of Learning Support Center, Biology, and General Classrooms - $58,122

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Title:  Agreement for Design Professional Services
Vendor:  Verde Design
Agreement Date:  January 27, 2014
Campus:  Foothill College
Project Number:  100
Project Name:  Resurface Tennis Courts
Amount:  $40,000
For:
	 
Professional services for renovation of the tennis courts at Foothill College. Improvements to the courts will include resurfacing, restriping, replacing the fence fabric, replacing ball boards, replacing wind screens, and constructing a new retaining wall and walkway adjacent to the courts.  
	 
Funding for this project is available within project 100.
	 
Submitted by:
Charles Allen, Executive Director, Facilities, Operations, and Construction Management, extension 6150
Additional contact names:
Art Heinrich, Director, Bond Program Management, Foothill College
Is backup provided?
Yes
